abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. The relevance of
            the project key lessons stands on the fact that the
            Hurricane Emergency Project is part of a larger package of
            emergency assistance to Nicaragua, and will provide insights
            of general value, country-wise. It is suggested that for
            cases where the early involvement of the Bank is needed,
            prior to developing an emergency assistance strategy, the
            amendment of ongoing operations, and preparation of
            supplemental ones, should be the fastest vehicles to provide
            investment support. This is particularly relevant for
            disaster situations, when once the emergency assistance
            strategy is formulated, it would be best to process the
            assistance as separate operations, each one following its
            own pace. This strategy calls for a quick assessment of the
            country's macroeconomic situation, including
            complementary assistance, such as the management assistance
            provided by the Bank to the Central America Emergency Trust
            Fund, which was critical in ensuring emergency financing
            requirements would remain current, within the debt service
            obligations. While longer-term concerns about disaster
            management preparedness needs to be addressed, it would not
            be effective to combine this mitigation with emergency
            support objectives, but rather address same as components,
            or as separate stand alone operations.
